prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is about a girlfriend bringing her friend to the author's apartment, and he's becoming uncomfortable with their behavior.

First, I need to look at both sides. The author set up the situation where his girlfriend was staying with him temporarily until her parents made up. He was clear it was temporary. Then she started bringing her friend, and he's noticed a change in her behavior, becoming catty and rude. There are specific examples where the friend was dismissive or hostile towards him, like the sandwich offer and the game incident. The friend's comments about the man having an opinion, and the girlfriend's attitude when he wanted to stay in the living room. The author feels that the presence of the friend is making his girlfriend act differently and he wants to stop this by telling her not to bring her friend anymore.

Now, considering if the author is in the wrong. The user initially thought the author is in the wrong, but they want my opinion. Let me think. The author is a guest in his own apartment, right? He's the one providing the space. If his girlfriend is staying with him, and she brings someone else, there might be an expectation of privacy and respect. The friend's behavior towards him seems disrespectful. The author has a right to feel uncomfortable in his own home. 

But maybe the girlfriend isn't aware of how her friend is behaving. The author could have communicated his discomfort earlier. However, he's given multiple examples where the friend's behavior was clearly negative. He tried to be polite, like when he offered to make snacks and was shut down. The situation escalated, and the author wants to set a boundary. Setting boundaries in one's own home is reasonable. 

On the other hand, maybe the author should have addressed the issue with the girlfriend before cutting off the friend entirely. But the question is whether he's in the wrong for deciding to tell her not to bring the friend. Since the friend's presence is causing tension and the girlfriend is acting differently, the author is justified in wanting to protect his living environment. 

So, the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong. He has the right to set boundaries in his home, especially when the friend's presence is affecting his well-being.
